text: This blog is about visualizing Palmer Penguins Data Set.

title: Palmer Penguins Data Set Visualization Tutorial
text:
This is a tutorial on how to visualize the Palmer Penguins Data Set.
To do this, we need several steps:

title: Palmer Penguins Data Set Visualization Tutorial
text:
Step 1: Import necessary libraries
The Pandas library is primarily used for data manipulation and analysis, while the matplotlib library works well with NumPy and Pandas to visualize data directly.

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

title: Palmer Penguins Data Set Visualization Tutorial
text:
Step 2: Load data into Python
Run the cell below to load the penguin dataset as a pandas DataFrame called penguins.

url = "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pic16b-ucla/24W/main/datasets/palmer_penguins.csv"
penguins = pd.read_csv(url)

title: Palmer Penguins Data Set Visualization Tutorial
section: Step 3: Separate data into X and Y
text:
Step 3: Separate data into X and Y
Since we wish to create a scatter plot to model the penguin’s Culmen Length against Culmen Depth, we need to separate which column is going to be in the x-axis and y-axis.

X = penguins["Culmen Length (mm)"]
y = penguins["Culmen Depth (mm)"]

title: Palmer Penguins Data Set Visualization Tutorial
text:
Step 4: Visualize data using Scatterplot



alt text



A bird (probably not a penguin) getting its culmen length measured

Source:

MeasureBeakThrush
First let us create an empty figure and label the axes. We want to turn the plot into a scatterplot of the penguin’s Culmen Length against Culmen Depth.

fig, ax = plt.subplots(1)
ax.set(xlabel = "Culmen Length (mm)", 
       ylabel = "Culmen Depth (mm)",
       title = "Culmen Length vs Culmen Depth")

[Text(0.5, 0, 'Culmen Length (mm)'),
 Text(0, 0.5, 'Culmen Depth (mm)'),
 Text(0.5, 1.0, 'Culmen Length vs Culmen Depth')]









Our point in our scatterplot corresponds to one penguin’s culmen length and depth. To create the scatter plot, we will extract the unique species names from the Species column of the penguins data frame and ensure that each species appears only once by using the set function. We then iterate through through each unique species using a for loop.
In the scatter function, we then pass a short name for each species to an argument named label and a value of 0.5 for an argument named alpha which makes the points translucent. Run the cell code below.

species = set(penguins["Species"])
for s in species:
    sub = penguins[penguins["Species"] == s]
    ax.scatter(sub["Culmen Length (mm)"], sub["Culmen Depth (mm)"], label = s.split(' ')[0], alpha = 0.5)

Finally, run the next cell to add a legend and show our scatterplot. The plot will show different colors for different species.

ax.legend()
fig








Congrats! You have just made your first scatterplot!
